item.title: Micro-funds: Peer-producing Venture Capital (UPDATE 1)
item.description:
:::: entry-content Here’s my first crack at the Micro-Funds concept.Â  It’s related to the Social Venture Commons and Social Capital work I’ve been developing. They are all based on the new mode of organizing I see emerging.

*** I’ve also added an illustration of 3 alternative models that have emerged in recent conversations. They are all interesting in their own right and it may be more about using them in according to specific situations. All comments/suggestions/alternatives welcome. ***
{decoding=“async” fetchpriority=“high” height=“294” width=“500”}

item.title: Micro-funds and the Social Venture Commons
item.description:
::::: entry-content Working with the building blocks for a new kind of venture capital I’ve been shaping a couple of core components – micro funds, and the social venture commons.

Micro-funds: making small, flexible, intuitive, low-cost, high-leverage investments. Features:

  • Short life: fully invested within 3 years or less
  • Small, high-leverage investments: invest financial (e.g. $25-50k) and social capital{.zem_slink rel=“wikipedia”} in high-leverage ways – core capacity, incremental engagement, financial seeding
  • Low or no fee: offset with performance based incentives for financial and impact returns appropriate to the fund
  • Light-weight and dynamic operations: led by individuals or organizations that have a unique position or perspective on the ‘frontiers’ – run as a ‘side-car’ to existing occupation
  • Commons interdependent: fund and individual investments must spark and support a conversation and generally contribute to and engage community to mitigate risk, improve success, and demonstrate returns

::: {.zemanta-img .zemanta-action-click}

item.title: Building Blocks for a new kind of Venture Capital
item.description:
::::: entry-content ::: {.zemanta-img .zemanta-action-click}

:::

A new kind of venture capital for purposeful ventures is something I’ve been exploring for a number of years and was recently reenergized by some conversations at the OpenEverything retreat in September. I’m writing this now as I head to SoCap08 and looking forward to testing some of these ideas against other emerging models (e.g. Enterpreneur Commons) and amongst the worlds leaders in social venture investment. I’ll follow-up this post with any big insights that emerge and in the meantime I’m interested in any comments about what I’ve started framing below. Feel free to contribute in the comments or email me directly. And of course if you are buliding another model – feel free to take anything you gain from this and use or remix freely – just ping me and let me know what you are working on and share alike.

item.title: Union Square Ventures and a new kind of Venture Capital firm.
item.description:
:::: entry-content {.alignright decoding=“async” height=“162” width=“158”}Yesterday’s, NYTimes{.zem_slink rel=“homepage”} article on Union Square Ventures (USV) entitled “A New Kind Of Venture Capital Firm” is an interesting read and I’m glad to see the media beginning to pick up on this.

I’ve been following USV for a whlie now and actually interviewed Brad Burnham in preparation for a session at the Open Everything Retreat on Investing in Open. They seem to have a knack for investing in webtech ventures like Twitter{.zem_slink rel=“homepage”} and Wesabe{.zem_slink rel=“homepage”} that have models that can be deeply disruptive to the systems they are taking on and where the question of how they are going to make money from them is far from answered. And now they’re turning more of their attention to conventionally ‘social’ issues including education and the environment.
